title: Why I Still Invest, Even When the Market is at an All-Time High
subtitle: The case for maintaining a consistent investment strategy amidst market fluctuations.
content:
Why I Still Invest, Even When the Market is at an All-Time High

I'm Tyler, I'm a former financial advisor and portfolio manager. I make financial content for free so you don't have to pay for it.

1. Historical Performance

Since 1980, whenever the market's P-E ratio was above 20, considered too expensive, the average five-year return was still an impressive 75%.

2. Below 20 Valuations

Conversely, when valuations were below 20, average returns were 83%. Barely a noticeable difference.

3. The Bubble Fallacy

The "it's-over-valued" crowd has been shouting about a bubble since Reagan was in office. Meanwhile, those who remained invested in the market made 14 times their initial investment.

Conclusion

So stop waiting for perfect valuations; they simply don't exist. But do keep an eye out for regret, as that arrives much quicker. If any of this is helpful, sign up for my free weekly newsletter by clicking the link in my bio. Each week, I'll send you over another money playbook that actually works.
